facts.text: Suit instituted by appellant on a hundi for Rs. 10,000 dated 4th December 1947, drawn in his favour by Haji Jethabhai Gokuil and Co. of Basra on the respondents, who are merchants and commission agents in Bombay.
Hundi sent by registered post to appellant in Bombay, received by Parikh Vrajlal Narandas, who presented it to respondents on 10th December 1947 and received payment therefor.
Appellant had been doing business in forward contracts through Vrajlal as his commission agent and was residing at his Pedhi.
On 12th January 1948, appellant sent notice to respondents repudiating authority of Vrajlal to act for him and demanding return of hundi.
Respondents replied on 10th February 1948 denying liability, stating Vrajlal was agent of appellant and amount paid bona fide on his representation of authority.
Appellant instituted suit on 9th December 1950 in Court of City Civil Judge, Bombay, Suit No. 2310 of 1950, alleging payment to Vrajlal not binding and defendants liable on hundi.
Defendants pleaded reliance on authority of Vrajlal to grant discharge and that plaint disclosed no cause of action as no averment that hundi accepted by them.
At trial, appellant evidenced that Vrajlal received registered cover containing hundi in his absence and collected amount without knowledge or authority.
City Civil Judge accepted appellant's evidence, held Vrajlal not authorised to receive amount, plea of discharge implied acceptance, decreed suit on 24th July 1951.

Defendants appealed to High Court of Bombay, Appeal No. 811 of 1951, Chagla C.J. and Shah J. held no right of action without acceptance alleged in plaint, no cause of action, allowed appeal and dismissed suit on 9th September 1952.
Plaintiff (appellant) prefers appeal by special leave under Article 136 of Constitution.

legal_issues.text: Whether drawee of negotiable instrument liable to payee without acceptance.
Whether valid presentment for acceptance where presenter (Vrajlal) lacked authority.
Whether acceptance can be implied from payment, possession of hundi, or plea of discharge.
Whether plaint discloses cause of action without averment of acceptance.

petitioner_arguments.text: Payment to Vrajlal not binding on appellant as without authority.
Acceptance implied from respondents receiving bill and making payment, acknowledging liability to lawful holder.
Plea of discharge by respondents implies acknowledgment of liability, sufficient for right of action.
Possession of hundi by defendants constitutes acceptance.

respondent_arguments.text: Vrajlal was agent of appellant authorised to receive payment.
Plaint discloses no cause of action as no averment of acceptance by drawees.

court_reasoning.text: Drawee not liable to payee unless accepts bill; liability arises only on acceptance per Section 32 NI Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No provision makes drawee liable as such except in cheque cases under s.31.

court_reasoning.text: For bill payable on demand (hundi), presentment for acceptance and payment synchronise; valid presentment requires authority of presenter to receive payment under s.78.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vrajlal lacked authority, so no valid presentment.

court_reasoning.text: Acceptance must be signed assent on bill per s.7 NI Act; no oral or implied acceptance by conduct or possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment without valid presentment does not imply acceptance.

court_reasoning.text: Plea of discharge does not constitute acceptance; must be written and signed on bill.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Acknowledgment of liability insufficient without formal acceptance.

court_reasoning.text: Plaint lacks averment of acceptance, no cause of action.

holdings.text: Drawee of negotiable instrument not liable to payee without acceptance.
No valid presentment by unauthorised agent.
Acceptance cannot be implied from payment, possession, or plea of discharge; must comply with s.7 NI Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Where no acceptance, no cause of action to payee against drawee.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Ravji Jambhekar v. Pralhaddas Subkarn
precedents_cited.relevance: Presentment for acceptance precedes presentment for payment.
Under common law, verbal acceptance valid.
Implied acceptance from undue retention under common law.

statutes_cited.name: Negotiable Instruments Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines acceptance, liability of acceptor, presentment requirements.

statutes_cited.name: Bills of Exchange Act, 1882 (England)
statutes_cited.relevance: Acceptance must be written and signed; followed in NI Act s.7.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment, holding no valid acceptance or presentment of hundi, no liability on drawees, suit not maintainable for lack of cause of action.

key_quotes.text: "Where there is no acceptance, no cause of action can have arisen to the payee against the drawee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Elementary law on drawee liability cited from precedent.

key_quotes.text: "It is acceptance that establishes privity on the instrument between the payee and the drawee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reason no action maintainable without acceptance.

key_quotes.text: "The drawee becomes an acceptor, when he has signed his assent upon the bill."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting s.7 NI Act on formal acceptance requirement.
